content.raw:
I'm realizing that I added gtest somewhat prematurely. There were some other header utilities that I was thinking about adding to `ign-cmake` which would have required gtest for testing, but I left those other utilities out of this PR.

We could remove `gtest` from this PR, or we could leave it in since it may be useful later. For example, we could have `ign-cmake` install a gtest component that could be used by the other ignition projects. That would save us a significant amount of duplication, and could make maintenance easier every time we need to modify our version of `gtest`. But we could also leave that for a later PR.
content.html:
I'm realizing that I added gtest somewhat prematurely. There were some other header utilities that I was thinking about adding to ign-cmake which would have required gtest for testing, but I left those other utilities out of this PR.

We could remove gtest from this PR, or we could leave it in since it may be useful later. For example, we could have ign-cmake install a gtest component that could be used by the other ignition projects. That would save us a significant amount of duplication, and could make maintenance easier every time we need to modify our version of gtest. But we could also leave that for a later PR.

content.raw:
I investigated this some more.

I think the reason for the discrepancy between Windows and Unix might actually be the way Windows uses generators. I noticed that on Ubuntu, the `ignition-cmake1-utilities-targets.cmake` file *was* getting created and placed in the build directory, even though that didn’t seem to be happening on Windows. Maybe Windows defers file configuration until the end of the build system? Or maybe it gets deferred until generation time?

Whatever the case may be, I came up with an alternative fake install scheme which seemed to work for me on both Windows and Ubuntu: e530748

Basically, whenever testing is enabled, we do a duplicated configure of `ign-cmake` within a subdirectory of the build folder and then install that duplicated configure to an “install” folder, also in the build directory. Of course we disable testing for the duplicate configure, because otherwise we would get infinite recursion.

Now we should always get an exact replica of an `ign-cmake` installation for the tests.
content.html:
I investigated this some more.

I think the reason for the discrepancy between Windows and Unix might actually be the way Windows uses generators. I noticed that on Ubuntu, the ignition-cmake1-utilities-targets.cmake file was getting created and placed in the build directory, even though that didn’t seem to be happening on Windows. Maybe Windows defers file configuration until the end of the build system? Or maybe it gets deferred until generation time?

Whatever the case may be, I came up with an alternative fake install scheme which seemed to work for me on both Windows and Ubuntu: e530748

Basically, whenever testing is enabled, we do a duplicated configure of ign-cmake within a subdirectory of the build folder and then install that duplicated configure to an “install” folder, also in the build directory. Of course we disable testing for the duplicate configure, because otherwise we would get infinite recursion.

Now we should always get an exact replica of an ign-cmake installation for the tests.

content.raw: yeah, that's a better way to do a fake install
content.html: yeah, that's a better way to do a fake install

content.raw:
My concern is more about `testrunner.bash`.

As far as I can tell, we're not doing any `static_assertion` tests on Windows, because the `static_assertion` tests depend on `testrunner.bash`. I would guess that we need an equivalent `testrunner.batch` script for Windows.
content.html:
My concern is more about testrunner.bash.

As far as I can tell, we're not doing any static_assertion tests on Windows, because the static_assertion tests depend on testrunner.bash. I would guess that we need an equivalent testrunner.batch script for Windows.

content.raw:
this line causes an error in appveyor, complaining that `ignition-cmake1-utilities-targets.cmake` does not exist

~~~
CMake Error: File C:/projects/ign-cmake/build/ignition-cmake1-utilities-targets.cmake does not exist.
CMake Error at CMakeLists.txt:171 (configure_file):
~~~

all our other CI jobs passed because this line of code is not executed for `UNIX` or if `BUILD_TESTING` is false (since our [configure.bat](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-cmake/src/c45056187ec1f97f6502e2a8e7872344c8823526/configure.bat#lines-13) for windows CI invokes cmake the first time with `BUILD_TESTING`=Off). By tweaking the logic for debugging purposes, I've been able to reproduce this failure on all platforms.

I think the problem is that `export` happens after `configure_file`?

CMake Error at CMakeLists.txt:171 (configure_file):

all our other CI jobs passed because this line of code is not executed for UNIX or if BUILD_TESTING is false (since our configure.bat for windows CI invokes cmake the first time with BUILD_TESTING=Off). By tweaking the logic for debugging purposes, I've been able to reproduce this failure on all platforms.

I think the problem is that export happens after configure_file?

content.raw:
This might be what you're already saying, but I think the issue is that the `export` and `install` commands skip over putting the target file into the build directory. After all, the build system itself doesn’t need to dump the target information into a file since that information is readily available to it in memory.

I suspect the best way to handle this would be to try to do a real fake install instead of trying to spoof a fake install. That should also have the benefit of making this script maintainable. I’ll admit that I don’t know a way of doing that off the top of my head, but I have a feeling we’re not the first people to need that kind of functionality from cmake.
content.html:

After all, the build system itself doesn’t need to dump the target information into a file since that information is readily available to it in memory.

I suspect the best way to handle this would be to try to do a real fake install instead of trying to spoof a fake install. That should also have the benefit of making this script maintainable. I’ll admit that I don’t know a way of doing that off the top of my head, but I have a feeling we’re not the first people to need that kind of functionality from cmake.

content.raw:
Also, I’m suddenly realizing that the test doesn’t actually test what we want.

The test is testing that the compiler emits the warning, but it doesn’t test that our macro suppresses it. Somehow we need to set up this test so that it only passes if the warning is NOT emitted.

Maybe we can keep the `-Wall -Werror` and then test that the translation unit *does* compile without warnings when the macro is being used. We know that this setup will fail to compile when the macro is *not* in use, so if it does compile when the macro *is* being used, then the test should be considered to pass.
content.html:
Also, I’m suddenly realizing that the test doesn’t actually test what we want.

The test is testing that the compiler emits the warning, but it doesn’t test that our macro suppresses it. Somehow we need to set up this test so that it only passes if the warning is NOT emitted.

Maybe we can keep the -Wall -Werror and then test that the translation unit does compile without warnings when the macro is being used. We know that this setup will fail to compile when the macro is not in use, so if it does compile when the macro is being used, then the test should be considered to pass.

content.raw: that sounds good. it should also be less brittle by not needing the regex expressions of the compiler output
content.html: that sounds good. it should also be less brittle by not needing the regex expressions of the compiler output

content.raw:
Yeah, jenkins doesn't catch the `static_assert` tests in other repos either

* https://build.osrfoundation.org/view/os_homebrew/job/ignition_common-ci-default-homebrew-amd64/112/testReport/(root)/

the only thing that really notices them is the pipelines, which are only ubuntu, so nothing was flagging that the test was failing on homebrew.

I generate junit files for the examples tests here in ign-cmake but using `configure_file` to create pass and fail files. The `test_results` folder initially has the "failure" file, and then the test copies the "pass" file if it succeeds. gtest makes it  a lot easier
content.html:
Yeah, jenkins doesn't catch the static_assert tests in other repos either

  • https://build.osrfoundation.org/view/os_homebrew/job/ignition_common-ci-default-homebrew-amd64/112/testReport/(root)/

the only thing that really notices them is the pipelines, which are only ubuntu, so nothing was flagging that the test was failing on homebrew.

I generate junit files for the examples tests here in ign-cmake but using configure_file to create pass and fail files. The test_results folder initially has the "failure" file, and then the test copies the "pass" file if it succeeds. gtest makes it a lot easier

content.raw:
The test has been modified 7b488c1 so that if the warning doesn’t get suppressed, then the target will fail to compile. Jenkins should catch that as a standard compilation error without needing junit.

I’ve also updated it to work for Windows: 3424c23

It turns out that Windows needs the warning suppression in a different location than UNIX does, but the concern that’s being suppressed is sort of essentially the same thing, so I’m having them continue to use the same macro name. If anyone feels that the different platforms should use different macro names, I’d be completely fine with that, and I can make that change.
content.html:
The test has been modified 7b488c1 so that if the warning doesn’t get suppressed, then the target will fail to compile. Jenkins should catch that as a standard compilation error without needing junit.

I’ve also updated it to work for Windows: 3424c23

It turns out that Windows needs the warning suppression in a different location than UNIX does, but the concern that’s being suppressed is sort of essentially the same thing, so I’m having them continue to use the same macro name. If anyone feels that the different platforms should use different macro names, I’d be completely fine with that, and I can make that change.
